    Biography
   



    Act One
   


   Alexander Hamilton was born in the West Indies region of the Caribbean. According to the musical, Hamilton's father left him and his mother, who died from a fever when he was 12. He then moved in with a cousin who committed suicide, which left him to fend for himself as he had no one else.
  

   When he became older, a hurricane destroyed his town. In others' time of need, and due to his exceedingly brilliant intelligence, the citizens of the town collected funds so that Hamilton could book passage on a New York-bound ship ("
   
    Alexander Hamilton
   
   "). When Hamilton arrived in New York he became interested in the up-and-coming American revolution. There he first meets
   
    Aaron Burr
   
   in New York City ("
   
    Aaron Burr, Sir
   
   ") and is then introduced to the rest of Burr's revolutionary friends and impresses them with his oratory skills ("
   
    My Shot
   
   "). He has long dreamed of laying down his life for a cause such as the revolution ("
   
    The Story of Tonight
   
   ") and studied furiously before joining the Revolution, and becoming George Washington's secretary during the war. ("
   
    Right Hand Man
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton then attends a winter ball ("
   
    A Winter's Ball
   
   "), where he meets
   
    Elizabeth Schuyler.
   
   They talk to each other through letters for two weeks and eventually marry ("
   "). Her sister also had feelings for him, but Angelica allows Eliza to marry Hamilton, because she 'loves her sister more than anything in this life'. ("
   
    Satisfied
   
   ").
  

   General
   
    George Washington
   
   sends Hamilton home during the war for disobeying direct orders and engaging in a duel with General
   
    Charles Lee
   
   ("
   
    Meet Me Inside
   
   "). However, soon after he was summoned back, ("
   
    Guns And Ships
   
   ") to finish the war at the Battle of Yorktown. ("
   
    Yorktown (The World Turned Upside Down)
   
   ").
  

   After the war, Eliza gives birth to a baby boy named
   
    Philip Hamilton
   
   , whose innocent brilliance leaves him astounded ("
   
    Dear Theodosia
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton returns to New York to finish his studies and pursue a law career. Hamilton is then chosen as a delegate to the Constitutional Convention in the summer of 1787. Hamilton enlists
   
    James Madison
   
   and John Jay to write The Federalist Papers after Aaron Burr refuses. The newly elected President Washington enlists Hamilton for the job of Secretary of Treasury, despite Eliza's pleas. ("
   
    Non-Stop
   
   ").
  


    Act Two
   


   After
   
    Thomas Jefferson
   
   returns from France in 1789, Jefferson and Hamilton debate over the merits of Hamilton's financial plan during a Cabinet meeting. Washington pulls Hamilton aside and tells him to figure out a compromise to win over Congress. ("
   
    Cabinet Battle #1
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton's son turns nine, and he corresponds with Angelica in England, where she advises him to sway Jefferson so that Congress accepts his plan. Angelica travels back to New York to go upstate with his family but he refuses insisting he has to work. ("
   
    Take A Break
   
   ").
  

   While alone,
   
    Maria Reynolds
   
   visits Hamilton, who seduces him by claiming that her husband mistreats her. They continue to have an affair for a month until Maria's husband
   
    James Reynolds
   
   blackmails Hamilton into paying him money. In return, Reynolds will not tell Eliza about the affair. Hamilton agrees to pay Reynolds and continues the affair. ("
   
    Say No To This
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton discusses his plan with Jefferson and Madison over a private dinner, which results in the Compromise of 1790, giving support to Hamilton's financial plan in exchange for moving the United States capital from New York to Washington, D.C., a site that is much closer to Jefferson's home in Virginia ("
   
    The Room Where It Happens
   
   ").
  

   In another cabinet meeting, Jefferson and Hamilton argue over whether the United States should assist France in their revolution. Washington ultimately agrees with Hamilton's argument of neutrality ("
   
    Cabinet Battle #2
   
   ").
  

   As Washington steps down from his presidential position, Hamilton drafts his farewell address. ("
   
    One Last Time
   
   ").
  

   Now having no political office since the election of John Adams, Hamilton is outraged by Adams's "unprepared" nature according to Hamilton. They get in a fight with Adams bashing Hamilton for being an orphan; Hamilton's response being very harsh to Adams's weight. Hamilton's reputation takes a blow from this, and his political enemies, Burr, Jefferson, and Madison, think that it is the perfect time to destroy him ("
   
    The Adams Administration
   
   ").
  

   Thinking they have discovered a scandal capable of destroying Hamilton, Jefferson, Madison and Burr accuse him of embezzling government money and committing treason. In reality, however, they found the transactions from his affair with Maria Reynolds. Hamilton, knowing that the truth is the only way out, tells them about his affair and begs them not to tell anyone ("
   
    We Know
   
   "). Still worried that they would, Hamilton thinks about how writing openly and honestly has saved him in the past ("
   
    Hurricane
   
   "), and publicly writes "The Reynolds Pamphlet" to come clean about the affair, hoping to save his political legacy ("
   
    The Reynolds Pamphlet
   
   ").
  

   After his eldest child,
   
    Philip Hamilton
   
   , challenges
   
    George Eacker
   
   to a
   
    duel
   
   , he is mortally wounded and dies from infection ("
   
    Blow Us All Away
   
   "). Hamilton and Eliza become increasingly depressed after their loss and they move uptown ("
   
    It's Quiet Uptown
   
   ").
  

   As the Election of 1800 approaches, Alexander Hamilton is frequently asked about who he will promote for president. Shockingly, Hamilton selects Jefferson, claiming that Burr has no beliefs and stands for himself. ("
   
    The Election of 1800
   
   ").
  

   Burr, angry at his absent endorsement, challenges Hamilton to a duel in Weehawken, New Jersey ("
   
    Your Obedient Servant
   
   "). As a gunshot sounds, Hamilton soliloquizes on death, his relationships, and his legacy. He aims his pistol at the sky and is struck by Burr's shot, dying soon after. Burr laments that even though he survived, he's cursed to be the villain in history, remembered only as the man who killed Alexander Hamilton ("
   
    The World Was Wide Enough
   
   ").
  

   He now lies in Trinity Church, right near Angelica after she passed away. ("
   
    Who Lives Who Dies Who Tells Your Story
   
   ")

    Official description
   


   Lin-Manuel Miranda takes the stage as the unlikely founding father determined to make his mark on the new nation as hungry and ambitious as he is. From bastard orphan to Washington's right hand man, rebel to war hero, a loving husband caught in the country's first sex scandal, to the Treasury head who made an untrusting world believe in the American economy. George Washington, Eliza Hamilton, Thomas Jefferson and Hamilton's lifelong friend/foil Aaron Burr all make their mark in this astonishing new musical exploration of a political mastermind.

question: What is the musical about?
response: The musical "Hamilton" tells the inspiring story of Alexander Hamilton, an ambitious orphan from the Caribbean who rises to become a pivotal figure in American history. It follows his journey from a determined young man fighting in the Revolutionary War as George Washington's right-hand aide, to a war hero, loving husband to Eliza Hamilton, and the first U.S. Secretary of the Treasury, where he helped establish the nation's economy amid scandals and rivalries. Key characters include George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, and Aaron Burr, Hamilton's lifelong friend and eventual foe. The show explores historical themes of ambition, legacy, political intrigue, and the founding of the United States, all brought to life through a dynamic blend of hip-hop, R&B, and traditional theater.

From bastard orphan to Washington's right hand man, rebel to war hero, a loving husband caught in the country's first sex scandal, to the Treasury head who made an untrusting world believe in the American economy. George Washington, Eliza Hamilton, Thomas Jefferson and Hamilton's lifelong friend/foil Aaron Burr all make their mark in this astonishing new musical exploration of a political mastermind.

question: Who was Alexander Hamilton in Hamilton musical?
response: Alexander Hamilton is the central protagonist of the musical "Hamilton," portrayed as a brilliant, ambitious immigrant from the West Indies who rises to prominence during the American Revolution and early U.S. politics. Born in poverty, orphaned young, and arriving in New York, he becomes a key figure in the fight for independence, serving as George Washington's aide and later as the first Secretary of the Treasury. The musical highlights his key life events, including his marriage to Elizabeth Schuyler, his role in writing the Federalist Papers, his controversial affair and the Reynolds Pamphlet scandal, and his fatal duel with Aaron Burr. Through his story, the narrative explores themes of ambition, legacy, and the founding of America, emphasizing how his relentless drive shaped the nation's early history while revealing his personal flaws and tragedies.

       Trivia
      






    Biography
   



    Act One
   


   Alexander Hamilton was born in the West Indies region of the Caribbean. According to the musical, Hamilton's father left him and his mother, who died from a fever when he was 12. He then moved in with a cousin who committed suicide, which left him to fend for himself as he had no one else.
  

   When he became older, a hurricane destroyed his town. In others' time of need, and due to his exceedingly brilliant intelligence, the citizens of the town collected funds so that Hamilton could book passage on a New York-bound ship ("
   
    Alexander Hamilton
   
   "). When Hamilton arrived in New York he became interested in the up-and-coming American revolution. There he first meets
   
    Aaron Burr
   
   in New York City ("
   
    Aaron Burr, Sir
   
   ") and is then introduced to the rest of Burr's revolutionary friends and impresses them with his oratory skills ("
   
    My Shot
   
   "). He has long dreamed of laying down his life for a cause such as the revolution ("
   
    The Story of Tonight
   
   ") and studied furiously before joining the Revolution, and becoming George Washington's secretary during the war. ("
   
    Right Hand Man
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton then attends a winter ball ("
   
    A Winter's Ball
   
   "), where he meets
   
    Elizabeth Schuyler.
   
   They talk to each other through letters for two weeks and eventually marry ("
   "). Her sister also had feelings for him, but Angelica allows Eliza to marry Hamilton, because she 'loves her sister more than anything in this life'. ("
   
    Satisfied
   
   ").
  

   General
   
    George Washington
   
   sends Hamilton home during the war for disobeying direct orders and engaging in a duel with General
   
    Charles Lee
   
   ("
   
    Meet Me Inside
   
   "). However, soon after he was summoned back, ("
   
    Guns And Ships
   
   ") to finish the war at the Battle of Yorktown. ("
   
    Yorktown (The World Turned Upside Down)
   
   ").
  

   After the war, Eliza gives birth to a baby boy named
   
    Philip Hamilton
   
   , whose innocent brilliance leaves him astounded ("
   
    Dear Theodosia
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton returns to New York to finish his studies and pursue a law career. Hamilton is then chosen as a delegate to the Constitutional Convention in the summer of 1787. Hamilton enlists
   
    James Madison
   
   and John Jay to write The Federalist Papers after Aaron Burr refuses. The newly elected President Washington enlists Hamilton for the job of Secretary of Treasury, despite Eliza's pleas. ("
   
    Non-Stop
   
   ").
  


    Act Two
   


   After
   
    Thomas Jefferson
   
   returns from France in 1789, Jefferson and Hamilton debate over the merits of Hamilton's financial plan during a Cabinet meeting. Washington pulls Hamilton aside and tells him to figure out a compromise to win over Congress. ("
   
    Cabinet Battle #1
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton's son turns nine, and he corresponds with Angelica in England, where she advises him to sway Jefferson so that Congress accepts his plan. Angelica travels back to New York to go upstate with his family but he refuses insisting he has to work. ("
   
    Take A Break
   
   ").
  

   While alone,
   
    Maria Reynolds
   
   visits Hamilton, who seduces him by claiming that her husband mistreats her. They continue to have an affair for a month until Maria's husband
   
    James Reynolds
   
   blackmails Hamilton into paying him money. In return, Reynolds will not tell Eliza about the affair. Hamilton agrees to pay Reynolds and continues the affair. ("
   
    Say No To This
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton discusses his plan with Jefferson and Madison over a private dinner, which results in the Compromise of 1790, giving support to Hamilton's financial plan in exchange for moving the United States capital from New York to Washington, D.C., a site that is much closer to Jefferson's home in Virginia ("
   
    The Room Where It Happens
   
   ").
  

   In another cabinet meeting, Jefferson and Hamilton argue over whether the United States should assist France in their revolution. Washington ultimately agrees with Hamilton's argument of neutrality ("
   
    Cabinet Battle #2
   
   ").
  

   As Washington steps down from his presidential position, Hamilton drafts his farewell address. ("
   
    One Last Time
   
   ").
  

   Now having no political office since the election of John Adams, Hamilton is outraged by Adams's "unprepared" nature according to Hamilton. They get in a fight with Adams bashing Hamilton for being an orphan; Hamilton's response being very harsh to Adams's weight. Hamilton's reputation takes a blow from this, and his political enemies, Burr, Jefferson, and Madison, think that it is the perfect time to destroy him ("
   
    The Adams Administration
   
   ").
  

   Thinking they have discovered a scandal capable of destroying Hamilton, Jefferson, Madison and Burr accuse him of embezzling government money and committing treason. In reality, however, they found the transactions from his affair with Maria Reynolds. Hamilton, knowing that the truth is the only way out, tells them about his affair and begs them not to tell anyone ("
   
    We Know
   
   "). Still worried that they would, Hamilton thinks about how writing openly and honestly has saved him in the past ("
   
    Hurricane
   
   "), and publicly writes "The Reynolds Pamphlet" to come clean about the affair, hoping to save his political legacy ("
   
    The Reynolds Pamphlet
   
   ").
  

   After his eldest child,
   
    Philip Hamilton
   
   , challenges
   
    George Eacker
   
   to a
   
    duel
   
   , he is mortally wounded and dies from infection ("
   
    Blow Us All Away
   
   "). Hamilton and Eliza become increasingly depressed after their loss and they move uptown ("
   
    It's Quiet Uptown
   
   ").
  

   As the Election of 1800 approaches, Alexander Hamilton is frequently asked about who he will promote for president. Shockingly, Hamilton selects Jefferson, claiming that Burr has no beliefs and stands for himself. ("
   
    The Election of 1800
   
   ").
  

   Burr, angry at his absent endorsement, challenges Hamilton to a duel in Weehawken, New Jersey ("
   
    Your Obedient Servant
   
   "). As a gunshot sounds, Hamilton soliloquizes on death, his relationships, and his legacy. He aims his pistol at the sky and is struck by Burr's shot, dying soon after. Burr laments that even though he survived, he's cursed to be the villain in history, remembered only as the man who killed Alexander Hamilton ("
   
    The World Was Wide Enough
   
   ").
  

   He now lies in Trinity Church, right near Angelica after she passed away. ("
   
    Who Lives Who Dies Who Tells Your Story
   
   ")

student_goal: To understand the character of Alexander Hamilton as the central figure in the musical "Hamilton," including his historical background, key life events, and his role in shaping the story's narrative about the American Revolution and early U.S. politics.
pragmatic_need: To receive a straightforward and accurate summary of Alexander Hamilton's character in the musical for educational or informational purposes, helping the user quickly grasp his identity, actions, and legacy without delving into unrelated details from the context.

question: Who is Alexander Hamilton?
response:
Alexander Hamilton was a key Founding Father of the United States, born around 1755 or 1757 in the British West Indies. He played a pivotal role in the American Revolution, serving as a trusted aide to General George Washington and contributing to military strategies during battles like Yorktown. After the war, he became the first Secretary of the Treasury under President Washington, where he established the nation's financial system, including the creation of a national bank and writing influential essays like the Federalist Papers to support the U.S. Constitution.

On a personal level, Hamilton faced early hardships—his father left him, and his mother died when he was young. He married Elizabeth Schuyler in 1780, and they had eight children, including sons like Philip and James Alexander Hamilton. His life ended tragically in 1804 at age 47 or 49, after being mortally wounded in a duel with Aaron Burr, a rival politician.

The musical "Hamilton," inspired by Ron Chernow's biography, portrays him as the dynamic protagonist, highlighting his ambition, intellect, and flaws through songs like "My Shot" and "The Room Where It Happens." While the musical creatively dramatizes his story, it's based on real historical events, though it takes some artistic liberties for entertainment.

If you'd like to dive deeper into a specific aspect, such as his family, his economic policies, or how the musical adapts his life, what would you like to explore next?

    Alexander Hamilton
   
   is the titular main protagonist of the musical
   

     Hamilton
    

   .

       1

       Trivia
      






    Biography
   



    Act One
   


   Alexander Hamilton was born in the West Indies region of the Caribbean. According to the musical, Hamilton's father left him and his mother, who died from a fever when he was 12. He then moved in with a cousin who committed suicide, which left him to fend for himself as he had no one else.
  

   When he became older, a hurricane destroyed his town. In others' time of need, and due to his exceedingly brilliant intelligence, the citizens of the town collected funds so that Hamilton could book passage on a New York-bound ship ("
   
    Alexander Hamilton
   
   "). When Hamilton arrived in New York he became interested in the up-and-coming American revolution. There he first meets
   
    Aaron Burr
   
   in New York City ("
   
    Aaron Burr, Sir
   
   ") and is then introduced to the rest of Burr's revolutionary friends and impresses them with his oratory skills ("
   
    My Shot
   
   "). He has long dreamed of laying down his life for a cause such as the revolution ("
   
    The Story of Tonight
   
   ") and studied furiously before joining the Revolution, and becoming George Washington's secretary during the war. ("
   
    Right Hand Man
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton then attends a winter ball ("
   
    A Winter's Ball
   
   "), where he meets
   
    Elizabeth Schuyler.
   
   They talk to each other through letters for two weeks and eventually marry ("
   "). Her sister also had feelings for him, but Angelica allows Eliza to marry Hamilton, because she 'loves her sister more than anything in this life'. ("
   
    Satisfied
   
   ").
  

   General
   
    George Washington
   
   sends Hamilton home during the war for disobeying direct orders and engaging in a duel with General
   
    Charles Lee
   
   ("
   
    Meet Me Inside
   
   "). However, soon after he was summoned back, ("
   
    Guns And Ships
   
   ") to finish the war at the Battle of Yorktown. ("
   
    Yorktown (The World Turned Upside Down)
   
   ").
  

   After the war, Eliza gives birth to a baby boy named
   
    Philip Hamilton
   
   , whose innocent brilliance leaves him astounded ("
   
    Dear Theodosia
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton returns to New York to finish his studies and pursue a law career. Hamilton is then chosen as a delegate to the Constitutional Convention in the summer of 1787. Hamilton enlists
   
    James Madison
   
   and John Jay to write The Federalist Papers after Aaron Burr refuses. The newly elected President Washington enlists Hamilton for the job of Secretary of Treasury, despite Eliza's pleas. ("
   
    Non-Stop
   
   ").
  


    Act Two
   


   After
   
    Thomas Jefferson
   
   returns from France in 1789, Jefferson and Hamilton debate over the merits of Hamilton's financial plan during a Cabinet meeting. Washington pulls Hamilton aside and tells him to figure out a compromise to win over Congress. ("
   
    Cabinet Battle #1
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton's son turns nine, and he corresponds with Angelica in England, where she advises him to sway Jefferson so that Congress accepts his plan. Angelica travels back to New York to go upstate with his family but he refuses insisting he has to work. ("
   
    Take A Break
   
   ").
  

   While alone,
   
    Maria Reynolds
   
   visits Hamilton, who seduces him by claiming that her husband mistreats her. They continue to have an affair for a month until Maria's husband
   
    James Reynolds
   
   blackmails Hamilton into paying him money. In return, Reynolds will not tell Eliza about the affair. Hamilton agrees to pay Reynolds and continues the affair. ("
   
    Say No To This
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton discusses his plan with Jefferson and Madison over a private dinner, which results in the Compromise of 1790, giving support to Hamilton's financial plan in exchange for moving the United States capital from New York to Washington, D.C., a site that is much closer to Jefferson's home in Virginia ("
   
    The Room Where It Happens
   
   ").
  

   In another cabinet meeting, Jefferson and Hamilton argue over whether the United States should assist France in their revolution. Washington ultimately agrees with Hamilton's argument of neutrality ("
   
    Cabinet Battle #2
   
   ").
  

   As Washington steps down from his presidential position, Hamilton drafts his farewell address. ("
   
    One Last Time
   
   ").
  

   Now having no political office since the election of John Adams, Hamilton is outraged by Adams's "unprepared" nature according to Hamilton. They get in a fight with Adams bashing Hamilton for being an orphan; Hamilton's response being very harsh to Adams's weight. Hamilton's reputation takes a blow from this, and his political enemies, Burr, Jefferson, and Madison, think that it is the perfect time to destroy him ("
   
    The Adams Administration
   
   ").
  

   Thinking they have discovered a scandal capable of destroying Hamilton, Jefferson, Madison and Burr accuse him of embezzling government money and committing treason. In reality, however, they found the transactions from his affair with Maria Reynolds. Hamilton, knowing that the truth is the only way out, tells them about his affair and begs them not to tell anyone ("
   
    We Know
   
   "). Still worried that they would, Hamilton thinks about how writing openly and honestly has saved him in the past ("
   
    Hurricane
   
   "), and publicly writes "The Reynolds Pamphlet" to come clean about the affair, hoping to save his political legacy ("
   
    The Reynolds Pamphlet
   
   ").
  

   After his eldest child,
   
    Philip Hamilton
   
   , challenges
   
    George Eacker
   
   to a
   
    duel
   
   , he is mortally wounded and dies from infection ("
   
    Blow Us All Away
   
   "). Hamilton and Eliza become increasingly depressed after their loss and they move uptown ("
   
    It's Quiet Uptown
   
   ").
  

   As the Election of 1800 approaches, Alexander Hamilton is frequently asked about who he will promote for president. Shockingly, Hamilton selects Jefferson, claiming that Burr has no beliefs and stands for himself. ("
   
    The Election of 1800
   
   ").
  

   Burr, angry at his absent endorsement, challenges Hamilton to a duel in Weehawken, New Jersey ("
   
    Your Obedient Servant
   
   "). As a gunshot sounds, Hamilton soliloquizes on death, his relationships, and his legacy. He aims his pistol at the sky and is struck by Burr's shot, dying soon after. Burr laments that even though he survived, he's cursed to be the villain in history, remembered only as the man who killed Alexander Hamilton ("
   
    The World Was Wide Enough
   
   ").
  

   He now lies in Trinity Church, right near Angelica after she passed away. ("
   
    Who Lives Who Dies Who Tells Your Story
   
   ")
  


    Casting Changes

question: Hello. What is the musical about?
response:
Hello! "Hamilton" is a groundbreaking musical created by Lin-Manuel Miranda, which tells the story of Alexander Hamilton, one of America's Founding Fathers. The plot follows his journey from a orphaned immigrant in the Caribbean to a key figure in the American Revolution, his rise as a political leader, and his personal life, including his relationships and rivalries. It's inspired by Ron Chernow's biography and blends hip-hop, R&B, and traditional theater music to explore themes like ambition, legacy, the pursuit of the American dream, and the complexities of building a new nation.

Main characters include:
- **Alexander Hamilton**: The protagonist, a brilliant and driven young man who becomes a military aide to George Washington and helps shape the U.S. financial system.
- **Aaron Burr**: Hamilton's friend-turned-rival, representing caution and opportunism.
- **Eliza Hamilton**: Alexander's devoted wife, highlighting themes of love and family.
- **Angelica Schuyler**: Eliza's sister, who shares a intellectual connection with Hamilton.
- **George Washington**: A mentor figure, embodying leadership and the burdens of history.
- Other key figures like Thomas Jefferson and King George III add layers of political conflict and humor.

The musical's key themes revolve around resilience, the immigrant experience, the cost of ambition, and how ordinary people shape history. It's celebrated for its diverse cast and modern take on historical events, making it both educational and entertaining. If you're thinking about watching it, it's a must-see for its energy and emotional depth—I recommend checking out the original cast recording or a live performance!

question: Who is Hamilton?
response:
Alexander Hamilton is the titular main protagonist of the musical "Hamilton," which dramatizes the life of the real historical figure, a Founding Father of the United States. Born in the West Indies around 1755 or 1757, he faced early hardships: his father abandoned him, his mother died when he was 12, and a cousin's suicide left him orphaned. A hurricane later devastated his town, leading locals to fund his passage to New York, where he became involved in the American Revolution.

In the musical's Act One, Hamilton impresses revolutionaries like Aaron Burr with his skills, serves as George Washington's secretary during the war, marries Elizabeth Schuyler, and participates in key battles like Yorktown. In Act Two, he becomes the first Secretary of the Treasury, debates with figures like Thomas Jefferson, and faces personal scandals, including an affair with Maria Reynolds that leads to blackmail and public fallout. His career includes writing the Federalist Papers, clashing with John Adams, and endorsing Jefferson in the 1800 election, but it ends tragically in a duel with Burr, where he is fatally shot.

Hamilton's role in history, as portrayed, highlights his contributions to the U.S. financial system, his relentless ambition, and his complex personal life, ultimately shaping his legacy as a brilliant but flawed leader.

    The Room Where It Happens
   
   ").
  

   In another cabinet meeting, Jefferson and Hamilton argue over whether the United States should assist France in their revolution. Washington ultimately agrees with Hamilton's argument of neutrality ("
   
    Cabinet Battle #2
   
   ").
  

   As Washington steps down from his presidential position, Hamilton drafts his farewell address. ("
   
    One Last Time
   
   ").
  

   Now having no political office since the election of John Adams, Hamilton is outraged by Adams's "unprepared" nature according to Hamilton. They get in a fight with Adams bashing Hamilton for being an orphan; Hamilton's response being very harsh to Adams's weight. Hamilton's reputation takes a blow from this, and his political enemies, Burr, Jefferson, and Madison, think that it is the perfect time to destroy him ("
   
    The Adams Administration
   
   ").
  

   Thinking they have discovered a scandal capable of destroying Hamilton, Jefferson, Madison and Burr accuse him of embezzling government money and committing treason. In reality, however, they found the transactions from his affair with Maria Reynolds. Hamilton, knowing that the truth is the only way out, tells them about his affair and begs them not to tell anyone ("
   
    We Know
   
   "). Still worried that they would, Hamilton thinks about how writing openly and honestly has saved him in the past ("
   
    Hurricane
   
   "), and publicly writes "The Reynolds Pamphlet" to come clean about the affair, hoping to save his political legacy ("
   
    The Reynolds Pamphlet
   
   ").
  

   After his eldest child,
   
    Philip Hamilton
   
   , challenges
   
    George Eacker
   
   to a
   
    duel
   
   , he is mortally wounded and dies from infection ("
   
    Blow Us All Away
   
   "). Hamilton and Eliza become increasingly depressed after their loss and they move uptown ("
   
    It's Quiet Uptown
   
   ").
  

   As the Election of 1800 approaches, Alexander Hamilton is frequently asked about who he will promote for president. Shockingly, Hamilton selects Jefferson, claiming that Burr has no beliefs and stands for himself. ("
   
    The Election of 1800
   
   ").
  

   Burr, angry at his absent endorsement, challenges Hamilton to a duel in Weehawken, New Jersey ("
   
    Your Obedient Servant
   
   "). As a gunshot sounds, Hamilton soliloquizes on death, his relationships, and his legacy. He aims his pistol at the sky and is struck by Burr's shot, dying soon after. Burr laments that even though he survived, he's cursed to be the villain in history, remembered only as the man who killed Alexander Hamilton ("
   
    The World Was Wide Enough
   
   ").
  

   He now lies in Trinity Church, right near Angelica after she passed away. ("
   
    Who Lives Who Dies Who Tells Your Story
   
   ")

    Biography
   



    Act One
   


   Alexander Hamilton was born in the West Indies region of the Caribbean. According to the musical, Hamilton's father left him and his mother, who died from a fever when he was 12. He then moved in with a cousin who committed suicide, which left him to fend for himself as he had no one else.
  

   When he became older, a hurricane destroyed his town. In others' time of need, and due to his exceedingly brilliant intelligence, the citizens of the town collected funds so that Hamilton could book passage on a New York-bound ship ("
   
    Alexander Hamilton
   
   "). When Hamilton arrived in New York he became interested in the up-and-coming American revolution. There he first meets
   
    Aaron Burr
   
   in New York City ("
   
    Aaron Burr, Sir
   
   ") and is then introduced to the rest of Burr's revolutionary friends and impresses them with his oratory skills ("
   
    My Shot
   
   "). He has long dreamed of laying down his life for a cause such as the revolution ("
   
    The Story of Tonight
   
   ") and studied furiously before joining the Revolution, and becoming George Washington's secretary during the war. ("
   
    Right Hand Man
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton then attends a winter ball ("
   
    A Winter's Ball
   
   "), where he meets
   
    Elizabeth Schuyler.
   
   They talk to each other through letters for two weeks and eventually marry ("
   "). Her sister also had feelings for him, but Angelica allows Eliza to marry Hamilton, because she 'loves her sister more than anything in this life'. ("
   
    Satisfied
   
   ").
  

   General
   
    George Washington
   
   sends Hamilton home during the war for disobeying direct orders and engaging in a duel with General
   
    Charles Lee
   
   ("
   
    Meet Me Inside
   
   "). However, soon after he was summoned back, ("
   
    Guns And Ships
   
   ") to finish the war at the Battle of Yorktown. ("
   
    Yorktown (The World Turned Upside Down)
   
   ").
  

   After the war, Eliza gives birth to a baby boy named
   
    Philip Hamilton
   
   , whose innocent brilliance leaves him astounded ("
   
    Dear Theodosia
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton returns to New York to finish his studies and pursue a law career. Hamilton is then chosen as a delegate to the Constitutional Convention in the summer of 1787. Hamilton enlists
   
    James Madison
   
   and John Jay to write The Federalist Papers after Aaron Burr refuses. The newly elected President Washington enlists Hamilton for the job of Secretary of Treasury, despite Eliza's pleas. ("
   
    Non-Stop
   
   ").
  


    Act Two
   


   After
   
    Thomas Jefferson
   
   returns from France in 1789, Jefferson and Hamilton debate over the merits of Hamilton's financial plan during a Cabinet meeting. Washington pulls Hamilton aside and tells him to figure out a compromise to win over Congress. ("
   
    Cabinet Battle #1
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton's son turns nine, and he corresponds with Angelica in England, where she advises him to sway Jefferson so that Congress accepts his plan. Angelica travels back to New York to go upstate with his family but he refuses insisting he has to work. ("
   
    Take A Break
   
   ").
  

   While alone,
   
    Maria Reynolds
   
   visits Hamilton, who seduces him by claiming that her husband mistreats her. They continue to have an affair for a month until Maria's husband
   
    James Reynolds
   
   blackmails Hamilton into paying him money. In return, Reynolds will not tell Eliza about the affair. Hamilton agrees to pay Reynolds and continues the affair. ("
   
    Say No To This
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton discusses his plan with Jefferson and Madison over a private dinner, which results in the Compromise of 1790, giving support to Hamilton's financial plan in exchange for moving the United States capital from New York to Washington, D.C., a site that is much closer to Jefferson's home in Virginia ("
   
    The Room Where It Happens
   
   ").
  

   In another cabinet meeting, Jefferson and Hamilton argue over whether the United States should assist France in their revolution. Washington ultimately agrees with Hamilton's argument of neutrality ("
   
    Cabinet Battle #2
   
   ").
  

   As Washington steps down from his presidential position, Hamilton drafts his farewell address. ("
   
    One Last Time
   
   ").
  

   Now having no political office since the election of John Adams, Hamilton is outraged by Adams's "unprepared" nature according to Hamilton. They get in a fight with Adams bashing Hamilton for being an orphan; Hamilton's response being very harsh to Adams's weight. Hamilton's reputation takes a blow from this, and his political enemies, Burr, Jefferson, and Madison, think that it is the perfect time to destroy him ("
   
    The Adams Administration
   
   ").
  

   Thinking they have discovered a scandal capable of destroying Hamilton, Jefferson, Madison and Burr accuse him of embezzling government money and committing treason. In reality, however, they found the transactions from his affair with Maria Reynolds. Hamilton, knowing that the truth is the only way out, tells them about his affair and begs them not to tell anyone ("
   
    We Know
   
   "). Still worried that they would, Hamilton thinks about how writing openly and honestly has saved him in the past ("
   
    Hurricane
   
   "), and publicly writes "The Reynolds Pamphlet" to come clean about the affair, hoping to save his political legacy ("
   
    The Reynolds Pamphlet
   
   ").
  

   After his eldest child,
   
    Philip Hamilton
   
   , challenges
   
    George Eacker
   
   to a
   
    duel
   
   , he is mortally wounded and dies from infection ("
   
    Blow Us All Away
   
   "). Hamilton and Eliza become increasingly depressed after their loss and they move uptown ("
   
    It's Quiet Uptown
   
   ").
  

   As the Election of 1800 approaches, Alexander Hamilton is frequently asked about who he will promote for president. Shockingly, Hamilton selects Jefferson, claiming that Burr has no beliefs and stands for himself. ("
   
    The Election of 1800
   
   ").
  

   Burr, angry at his absent endorsement, challenges Hamilton to a duel in Weehawken, New Jersey ("
   
    Your Obedient Servant
   
   "). As a gunshot sounds, Hamilton soliloquizes on death, his relationships, and his legacy. He aims his pistol at the sky and is struck by Burr's shot, dying soon after. Burr laments that even though he survived, he's cursed to be the villain in history, remembered only as the man who killed Alexander Hamilton ("
   
    The World Was Wide Enough
   
   ").
  

   He now lies in Trinity Church, right near Angelica after she passed away. ("
   
    Who Lives Who Dies Who Tells Your Story
   
   ")

    James Alexander Hamilton
   
   was the third son and fourth child of
   
    Alexander Hamilton
   
   and
   
    Elizabeth Schuyler Hamilton
   
   .
  


    Hamilton was born on April 14, 1788
   

    When James was sixteen, his father was killed in a duel with
    
     Vice President Aaron Burr
    
    . Along with his mother and
    siblings
    , James was present in the room, sitting at his father's bedside, when he died a few hours after the
    
     duel
    
    .
   

    Hamilton served as acting
    Secretary of State
    to President Andrew Jackson and sided with Jackson in opposing the Second Bank of the United States, the successor to the bank which had originally been invented by his father
   

    His father's life and career, friends and rivals, are discussed at length in Hamilton's memoirs,
    
     Reminiscences of James A. Hamilton: or, Men and events, at home and abroad, during three quarters of a century
    


    He had 5 children, 3 of whom were named Elizabeth "Eliza" Hamilton, Alexander Hamilton Jr. and Angelica Hamilton

student_goal: To learn about Alexander Hamilton's identity, including his background, key life events, and role in history as depicted in the musical 'Hamilton'.
pragmatic_need: To deliver a concise and accurate summary of Alexander Hamilton's biography from the provided context to answer the question effectively and support the user's immediate informational requirements.

question: Who is Hamilton?
response:
Alexander Hamilton is the titular main protagonist of the musical "Hamilton," which dramatizes the life of the real historical figure, a Founding Father of the United States. Born in the West Indies around 1755 or 1757, he faced early hardships: his father abandoned him, his mother died when he was 12, and a cousin's suicide left him orphaned. A hurricane later devastated his town, leading locals to fund his passage to New York, where he became involved in the American Revolution.

In the musical's Act One, Hamilton impresses revolutionaries like Aaron Burr with his skills, serves as George Washington's secretary during the war, marries Elizabeth Schuyler, and participates in key battles like Yorktown. In Act Two, he becomes the first Secretary of the Treasury, debates with figures like Thomas Jefferson, and faces personal scandals, including an affair with Maria Reynolds that leads to blackmail and public fallout. His career includes writing the Federalist Papers, clashing with John Adams, and endorsing Jefferson in the 1800 election, but it ends tragically in a duel with Burr, where he is fatally shot.

Hamilton's role in history, as portrayed, highlights his contributions to the U.S. financial system, his relentless ambition, and his complex personal life, ultimately shaping his legacy as a brilliant but flawed leader.

   in New York City ("
   
    Aaron Burr, Sir
   
   ") and is then introduced to the rest of Burr's revolutionary friends and impresses them with his oratory skills ("
   
    My Shot
   
   "). He has long dreamed of laying down his life for a cause such as the revolution ("
   
    The Story of Tonight
   
   ") and studied furiously before joining the Revolution, and becoming George Washington's secretary during the war. ("
   
    Right Hand Man
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton then attends a winter ball ("
   
    A Winter's Ball
   
   "), where he meets
   
    Elizabeth Schuyler.
   
   They talk to each other through letters for two weeks and eventually marry ("
   "). Her sister also had feelings for him, but Angelica allows Eliza to marry Hamilton, because she 'loves her sister more than anything in this life'. ("
   
    Satisfied
   
   ").
  

   General
   
    George Washington
   
   sends Hamilton home during the war for disobeying direct orders and engaging in a duel with General
   
    Charles Lee
   
   ("
   
    Meet Me Inside
   
   "). However, soon after he was summoned back, ("
   
    Guns And Ships
   
   ") to finish the war at the Battle of Yorktown. ("
   
    Yorktown (The World Turned Upside Down)
   
   ").
  

   After the war, Eliza gives birth to a baby boy named
   
    Philip Hamilton
   
   , whose innocent brilliance leaves him astounded ("
   
    Dear Theodosia
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton returns to New York to finish his studies and pursue a law career. Hamilton is then chosen as a delegate to the Constitutional Convention in the summer of 1787. Hamilton enlists
   
    James Madison
   
   and John Jay to write The Federalist Papers after Aaron Burr refuses. The newly elected President Washington enlists Hamilton for the job of Secretary of Treasury, despite Eliza's pleas. ("
   
    Non-Stop
   
   ").
  


    Act Two
   


   After
   
    Thomas Jefferson
   
   returns from France in 1789, Jefferson and Hamilton debate over the merits of Hamilton's financial plan during a Cabinet meeting. Washington pulls Hamilton aside and tells him to figure out a compromise to win over Congress. ("
   
    Cabinet Battle #1
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton's son turns nine, and he corresponds with Angelica in England, where she advises him to sway Jefferson so that Congress accepts his plan. Angelica travels back to New York to go upstate with his family but he refuses insisting he has to work. ("
   
    Take A Break
   
   ").
  

   While alone,
   
    Maria Reynolds
   
   visits Hamilton, who seduces him by claiming that her husband mistreats her. They continue to have an affair for a month until Maria's husband
   
    James Reynolds
   
   blackmails Hamilton into paying him money. In return, Reynolds will not tell Eliza about the affair. Hamilton agrees to pay Reynolds and continues the affair. ("
   
    Say No To This
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton discusses his plan with Jefferson and Madison over a private dinner, which results in the Compromise of 1790, giving support to Hamilton's financial plan in exchange for moving the United States capital from New York to Washington, D.C., a site that is much closer to Jefferson's home in Virginia ("
   
    The Room Where It Happens
   
   ").
  

   In another cabinet meeting, Jefferson and Hamilton argue over whether the United States should assist France in their revolution. Washington ultimately agrees with Hamilton's argument of neutrality ("
   
    Cabinet Battle #2
   
   ").
  

   As Washington steps down from his presidential position, Hamilton drafts his farewell address. ("
   
    One Last Time
   
   ").
  

   Now having no political office since the election of John Adams, Hamilton is outraged by Adams's "unprepared" nature according to Hamilton. They get in a fight with Adams bashing Hamilton for being an orphan; Hamilton's response being very harsh to Adams's weight. Hamilton's reputation takes a blow from this, and his political enemies, Burr, Jefferson, and Madison, think that it is the perfect time to destroy him ("
   
    The Adams Administration
   
   ").
  

   Thinking they have discovered a scandal capable of destroying Hamilton, Jefferson, Madison and Burr accuse him of embezzling government money and committing treason. In reality, however, they found the transactions from his affair with Maria Reynolds. Hamilton, knowing that the truth is the only way out, tells them about his affair and begs them not to tell anyone ("
   
    We Know
   
   "). Still worried that they would, Hamilton thinks about how writing openly and honestly has saved him in the past ("
   
    Hurricane
   
   "), and publicly writes "The Reynolds Pamphlet" to come clean about the affair, hoping to save his political legacy ("
   
    The Reynolds Pamphlet
   
   ").
  

   After his eldest child,
   
    Philip Hamilton
   
   , challenges
   
    George Eacker
   
   to a
   
    duel
   
   , he is mortally wounded and dies from infection ("
   
    Blow Us All Away
   
   "). Hamilton and Eliza become increasingly depressed after their loss and they move uptown ("
   
    It's Quiet Uptown
   
   ").
  

   As the Election of 1800 approaches, Alexander Hamilton is frequently asked about who he will promote for president. Shockingly, Hamilton selects Jefferson, claiming that Burr has no beliefs and stands for himself. ("
   
    The Election of 1800
   
   ").
  

   Burr, angry at his absent endorsement, challenges Hamilton to a duel in Weehawken, New Jersey ("
   
    Your Obedient Servant
   
   "). As a gunshot sounds, Hamilton soliloquizes on death, his relationships, and his legacy. He aims his pistol at the sky and is struck by Burr's shot, dying soon after. Burr laments that even though he survived, he's cursed to be the villain in history, remembered only as the man who killed Alexander Hamilton ("
   
    The World Was Wide Enough
   
   ").
  

   He now lies in Trinity Church, right near Angelica after she passed away. ("
   
    Who Lives Who Dies Who Tells Your Story
   
   ")

    James Alexander Hamilton
   
   was the third son and fourth child of
   
    Alexander Hamilton
   
   and
   
    Elizabeth Schuyler Hamilton
   
   .
  


    Hamilton was born on April 14, 1788
   

    When James was sixteen, his father was killed in a duel with
    
     Vice President Aaron Burr
    
    . Along with his mother and
    siblings
    , James was present in the room, sitting at his father's bedside, when he died a few hours after the
    
     duel
    
    .
   

    Hamilton served as acting
    Secretary of State
    to President Andrew Jackson and sided with Jackson in opposing the Second Bank of the United States, the successor to the bank which had originally been invented by his father
   

    His father's life and career, friends and rivals, are discussed at length in Hamilton's memoirs,
    
     Reminiscences of James A. Hamilton: or, Men and events, at home and abroad, during three quarters of a century
    


    He had 5 children, 3 of whom were named Elizabeth "Eliza" Hamilton, Alexander Hamilton Jr. and Angelica Hamilton

    Official description
   


   Lin-Manuel Miranda takes the stage as the unlikely founding father determined to make his mark on the new nation as hungry and ambitious as he is. From bastard orphan to Washington's right hand man, rebel to war hero, a loving husband caught in the country's first sex scandal, to the Treasury head who made an untrusting world believe in the American economy. George Washington, Eliza Hamilton, Thomas Jefferson and Hamilton's lifelong friend/foil Aaron Burr all make their mark in this astonishing new musical exploration of a political mastermind.

question: What was Hamilton accused of in "We Know?"
response: In the song "We Know" from the musical Hamilton, Alexander Hamilton is accused by Thomas Jefferson, James Madison, and Aaron Burr of embezzling government money and committing treason. These accusations stem from suspicious financial transactions that were actually related to Hamilton's extramarital affair with Maria Reynolds, not any actual wrongdoing.

   ").

   In another cabinet meeting, Jefferson and Hamilton argue over whether the United States should assist France in their revolution. Washington ultimately agrees with Hamilton's argument of neutrality ("
   
    Cabinet Battle #2
   
   ").
  

   As Washington steps down from his presidential position, Hamilton drafts his farewell address. ("
   
    One Last Time
   
   ").
  

   Now having no political office since the election of John Adams, Hamilton is outraged by Adams's "unprepared" nature according to Hamilton. They get in a fight with Adams bashing Hamilton for being an orphan; Hamilton's response being very harsh to Adams's weight. Hamilton's reputation takes a blow from this, and his political enemies, Burr, Jefferson, and Madison, think that it is the perfect time to destroy him ("
   
    The Adams Administration
   
   ").
  

   Thinking they have discovered a scandal capable of destroying Hamilton, Jefferson, Madison and Burr accuse him of embezzling government money and committing treason. In reality, however, they found the transactions from his affair with Maria Reynolds. Hamilton, knowing that the truth is the only way out, tells them about his affair and begs them not to tell anyone ("
   
    We Know
   
   "). Still worried that they would, Hamilton thinks about how writing openly and honestly has saved him in the past ("
   
    Hurricane
   
   "), and publicly writes "The Reynolds Pamphlet" to come clean about the affair, hoping to save his political legacy ("
   
    The Reynolds Pamphlet
   
   ").
  

   After his eldest child,
   
    Philip Hamilton
   
   , challenges
   
    George Eacker
   
   to a
   
    duel
   
   , he is mortally wounded and dies from infection ("
   
    Blow Us All Away
   
   "). Hamilton and Eliza become increasingly depressed after their loss and they move uptown ("
   
    It's Quiet Uptown
   
   ").
  

   As the Election of 1800 approaches, Alexander Hamilton is frequently asked about who he will promote for president. Shockingly, Hamilton selects Jefferson, claiming that Burr has no beliefs and stands for himself. ("
   
    The Election of 1800
   
   ").
  

   Burr, angry at his absent endorsement, challenges Hamilton to a duel in Weehawken, New Jersey ("
   
    Your Obedient Servant
   
   "). As a gunshot sounds, Hamilton soliloquizes on death, his relationships, and his legacy. He aims his pistol at the sky and is struck by Burr's shot, dying soon after. Burr laments that even though he survived, he's cursed to be the villain in history, remembered only as the man who killed Alexander Hamilton ("
   
    The World Was Wide Enough
   
   ").
  

   He now lies in Trinity Church, right near Angelica after she passed away. ("
   
    Who Lives Who Dies Who Tells Your Story
   
   ")

   is the Broadway musical about the life of American Secretary of Treasury and Founding Father,

   , with the lyrics, music, and book written by

   and based off of the biography
   

     Alexander Hamilton
    

   by

   . The musical has made incredible box-office success in its Broadway production in the Richard Rodgers Theater as well as its Off-Broadway debut at The Public Theater in Manhattan.

    Background
   


   Production and lyrics of the musical began when Lin-Manuel Miranda discovered the biography
   
    Alexander Hamilton
   
   , by Ron Chernow, in an airport while on vacation from his other Broadway hit
   
    In The Heights
   
   (off-Broadway 2005-2007). While reading it on vacation in Mexico, Miranda began developing early ideas of a musical revolving Hamilton and his life. He began writing these ideas down, frequently shouting out ideas to his wife, Vanessa Nadal, as they came to mind. After researching, he found that a play by the life of Alexander Hamilton did exist, though it dated back to 1917. The first idea of Hamilton was brought up while Lin was at the bar with Jeremy McCarter. McCarter says "...Lin-Manuel Miranda told me he wanted to write a hip-hop concept album about the life of Alexander Hamilton. For a second I thought we sharing a drunken joke. We were probably drunk, but he wasn't joking."
  

   Adapted from the biography, Miranda began to draft lyrics and music in his spare time from
   
    In The Heights
   
   , and created the production
   

     The Hamilton Mixtape
    

   , brought to life by the
   
    Vassar Workshop
   
   (with
   
    Alex Lacamoire
   
   on the piano). The workshop earned a showcase at New York Stage and Film and gained very positive reviews from famous Broadway personalities. Miranda was later invited to the
   
    White House's Evening of Poetry, Music, and the Spoken Word
   
   , and, though he was set to perform music from
   
    In The Heights
   
   , he instead performed the opening number from
   
    The Hamilton Mixtape
   
   , the to-be version of the first song from the musical titled
   
    Alexander Hamilton
   
   .
  


    Lincoln Center Performance
   


   A few years after the idea came about, after a few of the songs had been written, Lincoln Center asked him to put on an American Songbook Concert. Tommy Kail suggested they get a band and orchestrate some of the songs to perform at Lincoln Center.
  

   "Lin opened the program with a set of songs he called 'the DNA of my brain.' These were [some of the] hits from some of his favorite rappers:.....Then he and his friends performed all of the
   
    Hamilton
   
   songs that [Lin] had produced so far."
   
    (Hamilton: The Revolution, Page 46, Paragraph 3)
   


   With increasingly positive comments on the snippet of
   
    The Hamilton Mixtape
   
   Miranda performed at the White House in the 2009 annual Poetry Jam, and then performed the workshop production of it at the Vassar Reading Festival, which was directed by
   
    Thomas Kail
   
   , with
   
    Alex Lacamoire
   
   playing the music.
  

   From there it reached its Off-Broadway production in The Public Theater, with an entirely different company (excluding
   
    Daveed Diggs
   
   as
   
    Thomas Jefferson
   
   /
   
    Marquis de Lafayette
   
   and
   
    Christopher Jackson
   
   as George Washington) and after its debut would perform live on Broadway.
  

   Its schedule to perform from July to September 2018 was:
   
    July 9-September 1, 2018: Tuesday @7pm, Wednesday @2pm and 8pm, Thursday @7pm, Friday @8pm, Saturday @2pm and 8pm, and Sunday @3pm
   
   .

    Plot summary
   



    Act One
   


   The musical begins by introducing the main protagonist
   
    Alexander Hamilton
   
   and sets his background as coming from a poor family, his father had left and his mother dying when he was 12 years of age. By use of his intelligence and "top-notch brain", Alexander travels to New York, in the developing nation of America, in hopes for a better life ("
   
    Alexander Hamilton
   
   "). Upon arrival in the summer of 1776, he immediately seeks out the young upstart
   
    Aaron Burr
   
   for advice, who in turn tells him to "talk less, smile more" ("
   
    Aaron Burr, Sir
   
   "). Alexander instead joins up with three revolutionaries:
   
    John Laurens
   
   ,
   
    Marquis de Lafayette
   
   , and
   
    Hercules Mulligan
   
   , and gains their friendship and trust in the Revolution by impressing them with his knowledge and skill ("
   
    My Shot
   
   "), and the four sing about earning their country by staking their lives for the cause (
   
    The Story of Tonight
   
   "). As news of the Revolution spreads and grows in excitement, the Schuyler sisters
   
    Angelica
   
   ,
   
    Elizabeth
   
   , and
   
    Peggy Schuyler
   
   sing about their hopes and prospects of the Revolution. ("
   
    The Schuyler Sisters
   
   ")
  

   The opposing Loyalist
   
    Samuel Seabury
   
   arrives and proclaims against the Revolution, while Hamilton defends the movement by opposing the Loyalist's actions ("
   
    Farmer Refuted
   
   "). A message then arrives from the king of England,
   
    King George III
   
   , explaining that the king will fight for the colonist's loyalty back ("
   
    You'll Be Back
   
   "). Despite this, Hamilton and his newfound allies go further to join the Continental Army, in which Hamilton is given and accepts a position as
   
    George Washington
   
   's right-hand man ("
   
    Right Hand Man
   
   ").
  

   In the winter ball hosted by
   
    Philip Schuyler
   
   in 1780, the men are in attendance, and they set their sights on the three Schuyler sisters ("
   
    A Winter's Ball
   
   ").
   
    Elizabeth Schuyler
   
   , the middle Schuyler sister, immediately fancies Alexander, and after they are introduced by her sister Angelica Schuyler, they are married by the blessing of Eliza's father ("
   "). Angelica, however, still has feelings for Alexander, but keeps them aside for the sake of her sister ("
   
    Satisfied
   
   "). Aaron Burr then meets up with Hamilton, Marquis de Lafayette, John Laurens, and Hercules Mulligan, and privately admits to Hamilton that he is having an affair with the wife of a British officer. Hamilton tells him to go for her ("
   
    The Story of Tonight (Reprise)
   
   "). However, Burr explains that he will wait for what life has in store for him, like how he has waited for everything else in his past ("
   
    Wait For It
   
   ").
  

   As the Revolution is underway, Hamilton continually asks Washington for a promotion and for a command, to which Washington denies. George Washington instead promotes
   
    Charles Lee
   
   , which leads up to an incredibly disastrous battle, in which Lee is demoted to Marquis de Lafayette. Lee then

question: What is the signficance of Alexander Hamilton?
response: Alexander Hamilton was a pivotal Founding Father whose significance lies in his transformative contributions to the United States' early government and economy, as well as his enduring cultural impact. Historically, he played a key role in the American Revolution as a soldier and aide to George Washington, helped draft the Federalist Papers to support the Constitution, and as the first Secretary of the Treasury, he established the national financial system, including the central bank, which stabilized the economy and promoted manufacturing. His ideas shaped the federal government's structure, emphasizing a strong central authority. Today, his legacy is vividly celebrated through Lin-Manuel Miranda's musical "Hamilton," which has popularized his story, highlighting his immigrant background, ambition, and complexities, inspiring a new generation to appreciate American history's diverse figures.

    Biography
   



    Act One
   


   Alexander Hamilton was born in the West Indies region of the Caribbean. According to the musical, Hamilton's father left him and his mother, who died from a fever when he was 12. He then moved in with a cousin who committed suicide, which left him to fend for himself as he had no one else.
  

   When he became older, a hurricane destroyed his town. In others' time of need, and due to his exceedingly brilliant intelligence, the citizens of the town collected funds so that Hamilton could book passage on a New York-bound ship ("
   
    Alexander Hamilton
   
   "). When Hamilton arrived in New York he became interested in the up-and-coming American revolution. There he first meets
   
    Aaron Burr
   
   in New York City ("
   
    Aaron Burr, Sir
   
   ") and is then introduced to the rest of Burr's revolutionary friends and impresses them with his oratory skills ("
   
    My Shot
   
   "). He has long dreamed of laying down his life for a cause such as the revolution ("
   
    The Story of Tonight
   
   ") and studied furiously before joining the Revolution, and becoming George Washington's secretary during the war. ("
   
    Right Hand Man
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton then attends a winter ball ("
   
    A Winter's Ball
   
   "), where he meets
   
    Elizabeth Schuyler.
   
   They talk to each other through letters for two weeks and eventually marry ("
   "). Her sister also had feelings for him, but Angelica allows Eliza to marry Hamilton, because she 'loves her sister more than anything in this life'. ("
   
    Satisfied
   
   ").
  

   General
   
    George Washington
   
   sends Hamilton home during the war for disobeying direct orders and engaging in a duel with General
   
    Charles Lee
   
   ("
   
    Meet Me Inside
   
   "). However, soon after he was summoned back, ("
   
    Guns And Ships
   
   ") to finish the war at the Battle of Yorktown. ("
   
    Yorktown (The World Turned Upside Down)
   
   ").
  

   After the war, Eliza gives birth to a baby boy named
   
    Philip Hamilton
   
   , whose innocent brilliance leaves him astounded ("
   
    Dear Theodosia
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton returns to New York to finish his studies and pursue a law career. Hamilton is then chosen as a delegate to the Constitutional Convention in the summer of 1787. Hamilton enlists
   
    James Madison
   
   and John Jay to write The Federalist Papers after Aaron Burr refuses. The newly elected President Washington enlists Hamilton for the job of Secretary of Treasury, despite Eliza's pleas. ("
   
    Non-Stop
   
   ").
  


    Act Two
   


   After
   
    Thomas Jefferson
   
   returns from France in 1789, Jefferson and Hamilton debate over the merits of Hamilton's financial plan during a Cabinet meeting. Washington pulls Hamilton aside and tells him to figure out a compromise to win over Congress. ("
   
    Cabinet Battle #1
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton's son turns nine, and he corresponds with Angelica in England, where she advises him to sway Jefferson so that Congress accepts his plan. Angelica travels back to New York to go upstate with his family but he refuses insisting he has to work. ("
   
    Take A Break
   
   ").
  

   While alone,
   
    Maria Reynolds
   
   visits Hamilton, who seduces him by claiming that her husband mistreats her. They continue to have an affair for a month until Maria's husband
   
    James Reynolds
   
   blackmails Hamilton into paying him money. In return, Reynolds will not tell Eliza about the affair. Hamilton agrees to pay Reynolds and continues the affair. ("
   
    Say No To This
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton discusses his plan with Jefferson and Madison over a private dinner, which results in the Compromise of 1790, giving support to Hamilton's financial plan in exchange for moving the United States capital from New York to Washington, D.C., a site that is much closer to Jefferson's home in Virginia ("
   
    The Room Where It Happens
   
   ").
  

   In another cabinet meeting, Jefferson and Hamilton argue over whether the United States should assist France in their revolution. Washington ultimately agrees with Hamilton's argument of neutrality ("
   
    Cabinet Battle #2
   
   ").
  

   As Washington steps down from his presidential position, Hamilton drafts his farewell address. ("
   
    One Last Time
   
   ").
  

   Now having no political office since the election of John Adams, Hamilton is outraged by Adams's "unprepared" nature according to Hamilton. They get in a fight with Adams bashing Hamilton for being an orphan; Hamilton's response being very harsh to Adams's weight. Hamilton's reputation takes a blow from this, and his political enemies, Burr, Jefferson, and Madison, think that it is the perfect time to destroy him ("
   
    The Adams Administration
   
   ").
  

   Thinking they have discovered a scandal capable of destroying Hamilton, Jefferson, Madison and Burr accuse him of embezzling government money and committing treason. In reality, however, they found the transactions from his affair with Maria Reynolds. Hamilton, knowing that the truth is the only way out, tells them about his affair and begs them not to tell anyone ("
   
    We Know
   
   "). Still worried that they would, Hamilton thinks about how writing openly and honestly has saved him in the past ("
   
    Hurricane
   
   "), and publicly writes "The Reynolds Pamphlet" to come clean about the affair, hoping to save his political legacy ("
   
    The Reynolds Pamphlet
   
   ").
  

   After his eldest child,
   
    Philip Hamilton
   
   , challenges
   
    George Eacker
   
   to a
   
    duel
   
   , he is mortally wounded and dies from infection ("
   
    Blow Us All Away
   
   "). Hamilton and Eliza become increasingly depressed after their loss and they move uptown ("
   
    It's Quiet Uptown
   
   ").
  

   As the Election of 1800 approaches, Alexander Hamilton is frequently asked about who he will promote for president. Shockingly, Hamilton selects Jefferson, claiming that Burr has no beliefs and stands for himself. ("
   
    The Election of 1800
   
   ").
  

   Burr, angry at his absent endorsement, challenges Hamilton to a duel in Weehawken, New Jersey ("
   
    Your Obedient Servant
   
   "). As a gunshot sounds, Hamilton soliloquizes on death, his relationships, and his legacy. He aims his pistol at the sky and is struck by Burr's shot, dying soon after. Burr laments that even though he survived, he's cursed to be the villain in history, remembered only as the man who killed Alexander Hamilton ("
   
    The World Was Wide Enough
   
   ").
  

   He now lies in Trinity Church, right near Angelica after she passed away. ("
   
    Who Lives Who Dies Who Tells Your Story
   
   ")

question: Who is Alexander Hamilton?
response:
Alexander Hamilton was a Founding Father of the United States, born around January 11, 1755 or 1757, in the British West Indies. He played a pivotal role in the American Revolution, serving as a key aide to General George Washington and contributing to the victory at the Battle of Yorktown. After the war, he became the first Secretary of the Treasury, where he established the nation's financial system, including the creation of a national bank and promoting economic policies that shaped the early U.S. government.

Hamilton's personal life included his marriage to Elizabeth Schuyler Hamilton and their eight children, such as Philip and James Alexander Hamilton. His life ended tragically on July 12, 1804, after being mortally wounded in a duel with Aaron Burr.

Culturally, Hamilton's story gained widespread recognition through Lin-Manuel Miranda's musical "Hamilton," inspired by Ron Chernow's biography. The musical highlights his immigrant background, ambition, and contributions, making him a symbol of perseverance and early American history.

   was the third son and fourth child of
   
    Alexander Hamilton
   
   and
   
    Elizabeth Schuyler Hamilton
   
   .
  


    Hamilton was born on April 14, 1788
   

    When James was sixteen, his father was killed in a duel with
    
     Vice President Aaron Burr
    
    . Along with his mother and
    siblings
    , James was present in the room, sitting at his father's bedside, when he died a few hours after the
    
     duel
    
    .
   

    Hamilton served as acting
    Secretary of State
    to President Andrew Jackson and sided with Jackson in opposing the Second Bank of the United States, the successor to the bank which had originally been invented by his father
   

    His father's life and career, friends and rivals, are discussed at length in Hamilton's memoirs,
    
     Reminiscences of James A. Hamilton: or, Men and events, at home and abroad, during three quarters of a century
    


    He had 5 children, 3 of whom were named Elizabeth "Eliza" Hamilton, Alexander Hamilton Jr. and Angelica Hamilton

    Biography
   



    Act One
   


   Alexander Hamilton was born in the West Indies region of the Caribbean. According to the musical, Hamilton's father left him and his mother, who died from a fever when he was 12. He then moved in with a cousin who committed suicide, which left him to fend for himself as he had no one else.
  

   When he became older, a hurricane destroyed his town. In others' time of need, and due to his exceedingly brilliant intelligence, the citizens of the town collected funds so that Hamilton could book passage on a New York-bound ship ("
   
    Alexander Hamilton
   
   "). When Hamilton arrived in New York he became interested in the up-and-coming American revolution. There he first meets
   
    Aaron Burr
   
   in New York City ("
   
    Aaron Burr, Sir
   
   ") and is then introduced to the rest of Burr's revolutionary friends and impresses them with his oratory skills ("
   
    My Shot
   
   "). He has long dreamed of laying down his life for a cause such as the revolution ("
   
    The Story of Tonight
   
   ") and studied furiously before joining the Revolution, and becoming George Washington's secretary during the war. ("
   
    Right Hand Man
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton then attends a winter ball ("
   
    A Winter's Ball
   
   "), where he meets
   
    Elizabeth Schuyler.
   
   They talk to each other through letters for two weeks and eventually marry ("
   "). Her sister also had feelings for him, but Angelica allows Eliza to marry Hamilton, because she 'loves her sister more than anything in this life'. ("
   
    Satisfied
   
   ").
  

   General
   
    George Washington
   
   sends Hamilton home during the war for disobeying direct orders and engaging in a duel with General
   
    Charles Lee
   
   ("
   
    Meet Me Inside
   
   "). However, soon after he was summoned back, ("
   
    Guns And Ships
   
   ") to finish the war at the Battle of Yorktown. ("
   
    Yorktown (The World Turned Upside Down)
   
   ").
  

   After the war, Eliza gives birth to a baby boy named
   
    Philip Hamilton
   
   , whose innocent brilliance leaves him astounded ("
   
    Dear Theodosia
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton returns to New York to finish his studies and pursue a law career. Hamilton is then chosen as a delegate to the Constitutional Convention in the summer of 1787. Hamilton enlists
   
    James Madison
   
   and John Jay to write The Federalist Papers after Aaron Burr refuses. The newly elected President Washington enlists Hamilton for the job of Secretary of Treasury, despite Eliza's pleas. ("
   
    Non-Stop
   
   ").
  


    Act Two
   


   After
   
    Thomas Jefferson
   
   returns from France in 1789, Jefferson and Hamilton debate over the merits of Hamilton's financial plan during a Cabinet meeting. Washington pulls Hamilton aside and tells him to figure out a compromise to win over Congress. ("
   
    Cabinet Battle #1
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton's son turns nine, and he corresponds with Angelica in England, where she advises him to sway Jefferson so that Congress accepts his plan. Angelica travels back to New York to go upstate with his family but he refuses insisting he has to work. ("
   
    Take A Break
   
   ").
  

   While alone,
   
    Maria Reynolds
   
   visits Hamilton, who seduces him by claiming that her husband mistreats her. They continue to have an affair for a month until Maria's husband
   
    James Reynolds
   
   blackmails Hamilton into paying him money. In return, Reynolds will not tell Eliza about the affair. Hamilton agrees to pay Reynolds and continues the affair. ("
   
    Say No To This
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton discusses his plan with Jefferson and Madison over a private dinner, which results in the Compromise of 1790, giving support to Hamilton's financial plan in exchange for moving the United States capital from New York to Washington, D.C., a site that is much closer to Jefferson's home in Virginia ("
   
    The Room Where It Happens
   
   ").
  

   In another cabinet meeting, Jefferson and Hamilton argue over whether the United States should assist France in their revolution. Washington ultimately agrees with Hamilton's argument of neutrality ("
   
    Cabinet Battle #2
   
   ").
  

   As Washington steps down from his presidential position, Hamilton drafts his farewell address. ("
   
    One Last Time
   
   ").
  

   Now having no political office since the election of John Adams, Hamilton is outraged by Adams's "unprepared" nature according to Hamilton. They get in a fight with Adams bashing Hamilton for being an orphan; Hamilton's response being very harsh to Adams's weight. Hamilton's reputation takes a blow from this, and his political enemies, Burr, Jefferson, and Madison, think that it is the perfect time to destroy him ("
   
    The Adams Administration
   
   ").
  

   Thinking they have discovered a scandal capable of destroying Hamilton, Jefferson, Madison and Burr accuse him of embezzling government money and committing treason. In reality, however, they found the transactions from his affair with Maria Reynolds. Hamilton, knowing that the truth is the only way out, tells them about his affair and begs them not to tell anyone ("
   
    We Know
   
   "). Still worried that they would, Hamilton thinks about how writing openly and honestly has saved him in the past ("
   
    Hurricane
   
   "), and publicly writes "The Reynolds Pamphlet" to come clean about the affair, hoping to save his political legacy ("
   
    The Reynolds Pamphlet
   
   ").
  

   After his eldest child,
   
    Philip Hamilton
   
   , challenges
   
    George Eacker
   
   to a
   
    duel
   
   , he is mortally wounded and dies from infection ("
   
    Blow Us All Away
   
   "). Hamilton and Eliza become increasingly depressed after their loss and they move uptown ("
   
    It's Quiet Uptown
   
   ").
  

   As the Election of 1800 approaches, Alexander Hamilton is frequently asked about who he will promote for president. Shockingly, Hamilton selects Jefferson, claiming that Burr has no beliefs and stands for himself. ("
   
    The Election of 1800
   
   ").
  

   Burr, angry at his absent endorsement, challenges Hamilton to a duel in Weehawken, New Jersey ("
   
    Your Obedient Servant
   
   "). As a gunshot sounds, Hamilton soliloquizes on death, his relationships, and his legacy. He aims his pistol at the sky and is struck by Burr's shot, dying soon after. Burr laments that even though he survived, he's cursed to be the villain in history, remembered only as the man who killed Alexander Hamilton ("
   
    The World Was Wide Enough
   
   ").
  

   He now lies in Trinity Church, right near Angelica after she passed away. ("
   
    Who Lives Who Dies Who Tells Your Story
   
   ")

   visits Hamilton, who seduces him by claiming that her husband mistreats her. They continue to have an affair for a month until Maria's husband
   
    James Reynolds
   
   blackmails Hamilton into paying him money. In return, Reynolds will not tell Eliza about the affair. Hamilton agrees to pay Reynolds and continues the affair. ("
   
    Say No To This
   
   ").
  

   Hamilton discusses his plan with Jefferson and Madison over a private dinner, which results in the Compromise of 1790, giving support to Hamilton's financial plan in exchange for moving the United States capital from New York to Washington, D.C., a site that is much closer to Jefferson's home in Virginia ("
   
    The Room Where It Happens
   
   ").
  

   In another cabinet meeting, Jefferson and Hamilton argue over whether the United States should assist France in their revolution. Washington ultimately agrees with Hamilton's argument of neutrality ("
   
    Cabinet Battle #2
   
   ").
  

   As Washington steps down from his presidential position, Hamilton drafts his farewell address. ("
   
    One Last Time
   
   ").
  

   Now having no political office since the election of John Adams, Hamilton is outraged by Adams's "unprepared" nature according to Hamilton. They get in a fight with Adams bashing Hamilton for being an orphan; Hamilton's response being very harsh to Adams's weight. Hamilton's reputation takes a blow from this, and his political enemies, Burr, Jefferson, and Madison, think that it is the perfect time to destroy him ("
   
    The Adams Administration
   
   ").
  

   Thinking they have discovered a scandal capable of destroying Hamilton, Jefferson, Madison and Burr accuse him of embezzling government money and committing treason. In reality, however, they found the transactions from his affair with Maria Reynolds. Hamilton, knowing that the truth is the only way out, tells them about his affair and begs them not to tell anyone ("
   
    We Know
   
   "). Still worried that they would, Hamilton thinks about how writing openly and honestly has saved him in the past ("
   
    Hurricane
   
   "), and publicly writes "The Reynolds Pamphlet" to come clean about the affair, hoping to save his political legacy ("
   
    The Reynolds Pamphlet
   
   ").
  

   After his eldest child,
   
    Philip Hamilton
   
   , challenges
   
    George Eacker
   
   to a
   
    duel
   
   , he is mortally wounded and dies from infection ("
   
    Blow Us All Away
   
   "). Hamilton and Eliza become increasingly depressed after their loss and they move uptown ("
   
    It's Quiet Uptown
   
   ").
  

   As the Election of 1800 approaches, Alexander Hamilton is frequently asked about who he will promote for president. Shockingly, Hamilton selects Jefferson, claiming that Burr has no beliefs and stands for himself. ("
   
    The Election of 1800
   
   ").
  

   Burr, angry at his absent endorsement, challenges Hamilton to a duel in Weehawken, New Jersey ("
   
    Your Obedient Servant
   
   "). As a gunshot sounds, Hamilton soliloquizes on death, his relationships, and his legacy. He aims his pistol at the sky and is struck by Burr's shot, dying soon after. Burr laments that even though he survived, he's cursed to be the villain in history, remembered only as the man who killed Alexander Hamilton ("
   
    The World Was Wide Enough
   
   ").
  

   He now lies in Trinity Church, right near Angelica after she passed away. ("
   
    Who Lives Who Dies Who Tells Your Story
   
   ")
